content.body: The existing statement _‚ÄúFunction expressions in JavaScript are not hoisted‚Äù_ in MDN is correct, right?
content.formatted_body: The existing statement ‚ÄúFunction expressions in JavaScript are not hoisted‚Äù in MDN is correct, right?

content.body:
correct.

```
console.log(foo) // ReferenceError
void function foo() {}
```
Functions expressions do not need to be hosted because their binding is only visible inside their body, and no code can run before that binding initialization.
I dislike @[Ashley Claymore]'s example, because swapping the two statements doesn't remove the error
content.formatted_body: I dislike @[Ashley Claymore]'s example, because swapping the two statements doesn't remove the error

content.body: yeah it's more precise to say that 'hoisting' is not a thing which applies to expressions
fair üôÇ I was going for a minimal way to write a function expression
content.formatted_body: fair üôÇ I was going for a minimal way to write a function expression

content.body: üíØ agree that showing that there is no external binding at all is the more important core
* üíØ agree that showing that there is no external binding at all is the more important core

m.new_content.body: üíØ agree that showing that there is no external binding at all is the more important core

content.body:
> <@sideshowbarker:mozilla.org> looking at https://github.com/mdn/content/pull/11683

Looking at this PR, it looks like the contributor confuses the function expression with the variable declaration. It's not that function expressions are hosited like var declarations: it's just the variable which is hoisted.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @sideshowbarker:mozilla.org
looking at https://github.com/mdn/content/pull/11683
Looking at this PR, it looks like the contributor confuses the function expression with the variable declaration. It's not that function expressions are hosited like var declarations: it's just the variable which is hoisted.

content.body: Yeah, maybe it‚Äôs not clear to them that only the RHS is considered the function expression. Maybe an ast-explorer link would help
content.formatted_body: Yeah, maybe it‚Äôs not clear to them that only the RHS is considered the function expression. Maybe an ast-explorer link would help

content.body: nicolo-ribaudo: Ashley Claymore Thanks ‚Äî I added a comment at https://github.com/mdn/content/pull/11683#issuecomment-1004327053 that goes into a bit more detail.
